text:
I have been making this for over a year now. My family loves it. For all those people who give it less than 3 stars, try again with these instructions I learned from past reviewers. Use 1/3 cup butter, cook for only about 25 mins (do not let over cook, 40 mins too long), spoon juices all over the chicken 2 times while cooking. Perfect every time!

text:
I really think that Heather meant a 1/2 stick (1/4 cup) of butter. 

I marinated my 6 chicken breasts in a cup of lemonade prior to making this. I omitted the egg wash, as the lemonade marinade made the crumbs adhere well. I crushed my crackers up in a zipper type bag, added seasonings (LOTS of garlic powder, lemon pepper, paprika and onion powder), then added the chicken pieces two at a time. I also lightly coated a glass baking dish with vegetable spray. I added the coated chicken, sprinkled parmasen cheese evenly over the chicken, I melted 1/4 cup of butter and drizzled that over the top. Cooked it at 375 for 30 minutes. My whole family loved this! I served it with buttered parsley noodles n green peas. No leftovers at all! Think next time I'll have to double the recipe. This was a moist and very tender dish, very flavorful and was not greasy or extreme butter tasting either. Very easy to make too. I think I'll make up crushed crackers/seasoning baggies and have them ready to roll in my pantry on very busy nights! Thanks Heather!!! :o)

text:
Wow! I'd give this 10 stars if I could! Hands down THE juiciest chicken I’ve ever eaten. I generally hate white meat but decided to stick to the recipe here and used boneless breast filets, and I’m glad I did because it wouldn’t have been as pretty with dark meat. After reading myriad reviews here, I made a couple changes: I used an 8X8 Pyrex dish so the juices would stay put, I used only 1/2 of the required butter which was plenty, and I added about 1/4 cup of flour to the cracker crumbs so they’d adhere to the chicken better. The end result looked like KFC extra crispy chicken but tasted like pure heaven on a plate! Even my picky 2 year old loved it (when he saw his cubed portions, he exclaimed "nuggets!" and promptly devoured them.) This is definitely going into the regular rotation!

text:
Just made this recipe for dinner and it was a hit! I made the preparation easier by crushing the crackers in a gallon-size zip-lock bag and using my rolling pin on them -- my kids had fun helping--then adding spices (garlic and onion powder, a bit of salt and paprika)& shaking. After coating the chicken in the beaten egg, I put a few pieces at a time into the bag "shake 'n bake" style, shaking and pressing the crackers into the chicken, then pressing in more crumbs after I put the chicken in the baking dish. After cutting and adding the butter, on a whim I poured in a bit of white wine I had in the fridge and placed about 6 large cloves of garlic, sliced in half, around the chicken. The chicken smelled sooo good while baking and the garlicky butter sauce was delicous over noodles. I cut my chicken breasts in half, so next time will reduce the cooking time to 30-35 mins. Will definitely made it again, family loved it and is good enough (not to mention easy!) for company.

text:
I tried this recipe tonight because I wanted something quick and both me and my husband were impressed.  As others suggested, I cut the amount of butter in half, which turned out just perfect.  I also added 2 tsp. italian seasoning and 2 tsp. grated parmesan cheese to the cracker crumbs and sprinkled just a little garlic salt on top of the chicken before I put it in the oven.  This is one I will be making again.  Thanks for the quick, easy and DELICIOUS recipe!

text:
This was absolutely the best chicken recipe I've ever tried!  I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and added 2 tsp. Italian seasoning to the cracker crumbs, cut the butter to 1/4 cup and baked in a glass dish.  I also flipped the chicken over about halfway through the cooking time.  I used 3 very large boneless skinless chicken breasts and cut each in half.  My husband and I both loved this recipe!  The chicken came out so moist and juicy, I can't wait to make this one again.  I am planning on serving this at a slumber party for 8-10 year old girls also, I will use chicken tenders and various dipping sauces like honey mustard and BBQ.  Excellent recipe Heather, Thanks!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!!! But... I adapted it a bit and it turned out even better and more crispy. I made a garlic butter by putting four smashed garlic cloves into a low heat pan with 1/4 stick of butter, and a couple tablespoons of olive oil. Once the butter/oil was infused with the garlic, I removed the garlic and let the liquid become room temperature. I then coated the chicken (I used strips...three per large chicken breast) in the garlic butter and then into the cracker crumbs. The crumbs really stick just make sure the crumbs are small. I cooked them at 375 for 45 minutes, halfway through spooning a little of the leftover butter over each chicken tender. They were unbelievably moist, and crispy on the bottom and the top without turning. They also freeze very well. The garlic butter helped infuse great flavor throughout.

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Thats basically all it takes to summarize this chicken. It was WONDERFUL! 4 Stars after modifications- used one egg with a little milk for the egg wash, crushed up my ritz in a bag and added some Tony Chachere's, garlic powder and some parm cheese - Followed other reviews and used 4 Tbsp butter melted and poured in the pan and cooked for 25 mins turning twice and spooning the butter over the chicken- Also let this rest for 10 mins to really hold in the moisture and the result was 4 spotless plates! text:
Absolutely love it!  
Although, to be honest, I took the advice of other reviewers before trying it as is like I normally do - it just sounded so good with all the other stuff in it too.  I do intend on trying as is and will update when I do.  So here's the changes I made:
I used 1/2 stick of butter (1/4 cup)
1 tube of Ritz crackers
3 breasts because they were HUGE and I cut them into strips
1 tsp garlic salt
1/2 tsp pepper
1/2 tsp italian seasoning (might try less next time)
1/2 tsp onion powder
2 tsp grated parmesan cheese
all mashed up in a bag like shake-n-bake
I did use the egg then put it in the bag, had no problem with the crackers sticking.  Took about 35-40 minutes to bake at 375, but again, the breasts were huge, even cut up.
It was delicious and my husband doesn't want me to change anything... except maybe make more next time.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was SO delicious!  I followed the recipe, the only change I made was to the cracker crumbs. I used Ritz crackers with garlic powder, onion powder, fresh ground pepper, a pinch or two of chicken bouillon (which wasn't necessary, but I figured why not?) and a small handful of shredded cheddar cheese (just because I had some in the fridge and someone else had suggested it).  The first 2 pieces didn't really have a lot of breading on them, it wouldn't stick, so I double dipped the last 2 pieces and sprinkled the remainder of the crumb mixture over the top.  I used the amount of butter listed, putting a little bit on each piece of chicken and the rest in the bottom of the pan.  I flipped the chicken about halfway through the baking, and it came out crispy on the outside and moist on the inside!  Not at all mushy as someone suggested, it was a good texture.  We both loved it, I can't wait to try the leftover piece for lunch tomorrow.  I served this with mashed potatoes, gravy (I made a packet of McCormick chicken gravy) and steamed veggies...will absolutely be making this again!!

text:
This works nicely, but one trick I learned long ago is to season the meat, not the coating.  When adding the garlic salt, black pepper of whatever, you do not want it randomly showing up on some of the meat during the coating process.  It's better to always season the meat directly, then go thru your dredging process

Incredible. In the past year my family has decided that this is their favorite meal! I always add parmesan cheese into the cracker mix, as well as minced garlic. I often mix up the crackers,cheese and minced garlic - throw it into a ziploc bag and store in the fridge - very handy. We make chicken tenders with this, and have also topped the chicken at the very end with warm marinara or spaghetti sauce for a little something different! Thank you very much for this recipe!!!

I make this often, though I generally cut the chicken into strips and do it that way. I also add a packet of powdered ranch dressing mix instead of salt and pepper and it gives it amazing flavor. text:
Tried this recipe twice so far. I took the suggestion of others and added some extra seasoning (Trader Joe's 21 Seasoning Salute). The chicken was pretty tasty, but I only cook it for about 25-30 minutes (half the time on one side, half the time on the other). 

Here's the dilemma: cooking for 25 minutes produces perfectly cooked and moist chicken, but the breading is a little mushy. I've noticed other reviewers complaining of dried-out chicken. Next time I'll try 35 minutes, and hopefully it'll be just right.

text:
I tweaked the recipe to meet our needs, but the chicken turned out perfectly tender and crispy (thanks for the clue about halving the chicken breasts - they didn't cook unevenly this way). I used crushed Club crackers and 3 tsp. of Wildtree Garlic and Herb blend along with 1/2 tsp. of salt (this particular Wildtree blend doesn't include any salt). Put all of the dry ingredients in a large, plastic Ziploc bag, dipped each piece of chicken in the eggs, dropped the chicken in the bag, and shook to my heart's content. Thanks for this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
VERY good chicken! I did modify it a bit..but the base idea I think was very good. I used 3 chicken breast. (Note that it will most definitally cook in less time if you use tenderloins because they are thinner pieces of chicken) I put buttery crackers into my kitchen aid chopped and chopped it fine.I then added the ingredients called for but also added cayenne pepper powder, garlic powder, poultry seasoning, basil, paprika, and parmesian cheese.. I just did a few shakes of each. I then used 2 eggs beaten with a couple drops of milk...breaded my chicken and arranged in the pan. Now, I only used 2 tablespoons of stick butter cut into thin slices and arranged around and on top of the pan.. to make it lighter but still have the butter flavor. I cooked for 20 minutes on each side. Was very moist wihtout being over done and definitally a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this dish many, many times.  I've used it as a base recipe to try some variations as well.  For example, instead of dipping the chicken breasts in egg, I have tried ranch dressing as well as plain old mayo.  Both keep the chicken breast very moist and tender, and it helps create some variety to the recipe if you make it often.    To ensure that both sides stay crispy, I usually put the chicken on a greased Pampered Chef cooling rack that is then on top of a rectangular Pampered Chef baking stone (the cooling rack balances perfectly on top of it). This allows the air to circulate under the chicken and avoids one side getting soggy.  Great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cooking method does nothing kind for crackers or chicken. Omit the egg, dip the chicken in melted butter, and bake on a rack above your cookie sheet (so that the bottom doesn't get wet). I believe the beautiful picture that is luring everyone to make this recipe is actually crushed cornflake crumbs, which is a valid choice as well -- but not if you also use the egg wash. Note: I did not find the chicken bland or tasteless, I rather like the flavor of buttered, baked Ritz crackers personally. If you are unsure, by all means add whatever seasonings strike your tastebuds.

text:
Very good!  As soon as I took it out of the oven and served it, I went "This is my Mom's Chicken Parmesan!"  I used some advice of other reviewers: Added paprika and onion powder, sprinkled parmesan on top of the chicken, added 1/4c flour to cracker crumbs, and also put the crackers in a ziploc to crush with a rolling pin!  The bag broke though (cheaper plastic bag I found in italy- they don't really have "ziploc").  Also I don't think margarine exists here so i cut a few slices of butter and stuck them around the chicken and on top, along with another reviewer's idea of putting sliced garlic around the chicken! Delicious!

userID:
14102840
Display Name:
SeeJae
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We've made this several times over the last year, and we absolutely LOVE it. It's not a healthy meal with the heavy butter, but it's delicious and very filling. We use Ritz crackers for the coating and as much butter as we feel like, enough to cover the chicken. The first couple of times the chicken came out a bit bland - this is because we used margarine, so make sure to use BUTTER. Also, as other reviewers have said, spoon the melted butter onto the chicken a few times as it bakes in the oven. DON'T FLIP THE CHICKEN OVER OR IT WILL BE SOGGY. It doesn't have time to crisp up again if you flip it over, but if you spoon the melted butter on top of the chicken, it sinks into the meat and leaves plenty of time for the top to crisp again! Delicious recipe, love it!

text:
My husband works nights and this has become my go-to chicken recipe when I want to make something tasty but easy for him to eat when he gets home.  I've made it as written, and also made variations based on what I have on hand.  One favorite version is to pound the chicken flat and cut it into strips to make chicken fingers.  They don't take as long to cook as full breasts.  My husband is lactose intolerant, so I try to go easy on the butter.  Instead of placing it all around the chicken, I cut butter into small chunks and place a couple chunks on each piece of chicken which melt and coat the chicken, keeping it moist.  One time I substituted bread crumbs for crackers and it turned out just as good.  Another time I substituted coating the chicken in mayonnaise instead of egg before breading and it gave a slightly different flavor.  It's hard to screw this recipe up.
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I made this for dinner last night making a few changes.  I had nearly a pound of chicken (14 oz.) and I used one egg and only needed about half of it.  I used 1/2 cup crushed crackers and didn't need quite all of that.  I seasoned the chicken with garlic salt and pepper, then dredged it in flour, then dipped in egg, then in crumbs.  I was concerned the bottom would be soggy, so I only coated the top side of the chicken.  I melted the butter, cutting it back to just 2 T. and drizzled it over the top of the chicken.  For me, this was done after baking for only about 28 minutes.  The 40 minutes suggested in the recipe would have been too long.  This was good, but needed some pizzazz.  Next time I might try using half parmesan cheese and half the cracker crumbs for the crumb mixture.

text:
This was a huge hit, even for my picky 8 year old.  I used 1 sleeve of reduced fat Townhouse crackers, 1/8 cup flower and 1/8 cup of italian seasoned bread crumbs.  I used a plastic bag to "shake and bake" a couple at a time.  I used boneless breasts, each cut into 3 pieces so they'd be pick-up-able for the little one (cooked about 35 min total).  They were very moist and delicious!  I turned them twice during baking and amp'd up the heat to 425 for the last 5 or so minutes to get them a little crunchier. I served these with cauliflouwer mash and the Chicken Gravy from this site. Even though I didn't feel healthy eating this, I know I will make again!  Worth it :)

country:
None
text:
Delicious!  My husband even had seconds and my daughter just loved it.  I thought it was going to be bland and dry but thought to give it a try to do something different with chicken.  It was very moist and crunchy.  I read some of the reviews and thought to add a little here and there as well.  First of all, I seasoned my chicken beforehand(pepper, seasoning salt and onion power) and I also cut the breasts in halves.   I also added 1/4 cup of flour to crumb mixture to help the crumbs stick to the chicken plus onion power, garlic powder and paprika to the crumb mixture - all in a large ziplock bag.  After dipping in the eggs, I placed about 3 pieces of chicken in the bag with the crumb mix and shook until each was fully coated and placed in glass 9x13 pan - repeat until all chicken pieces are coated.  Any crumbs left over, I pressed it onto the chicken for extra crispyness.  Then I followed the recipe in regards to butter, temp and cooking time.  Can't wait for tonight's leftovers per my daughter!

country:
None
text:
EVERYONE WILL LOVE THESE! 

Great base recipe. I crumbled ritz crackers (about a cup) and added some italian seasoning and garlic salt to the mix. Next, I dipped the chicken tenderloins in the beaten eggs and rolled it around in the crumb mixture. Lastly, I put the tenderloins on a foil covered baking sheet and drizzled a mixture of melted butter (2tbs), white wine vinegar (tsp), and canned minced garlic(dash) over the tenderloins. I baked for 25 minutes @ 350 and flipped them half way. 

My goal was a delicious snack for movie night with my husband. We absolutely loved them...GREAT FLAVOR!, but they were a bit greasy to the touch. We wanted something we could pick up and dip in bbq, honey mustard, etc...though these didn't need any dipping sauce..maybe next time I will just try putting the broiler on for a bit to make them more crispy.

text:
I'm glad so many others here liked this recipe, but it just didn't do it for my family. I did try to jazz it up with extra garlic and herbs for seasoning, as others had suggested, and it certainly did smell wonderful while cooking... but the end result was just kind of ordinary. Yes, the chicken was moist... just not very tasty. I must be missing something, I guess!

This was a excelent chicken recipe. I have to admit I couldn't bake it like the recipe calls for, but instead I pan fried it. It still kept its nice and crispy outer coating and was nice and tender. So if you're little on time you can pan fry it. Also, this is a recipe with subtle seasonings, so you can add some more spices to your liking if you prefer a more flavorfull chicken, and still if it seems a little bland you can try adding a sauce like a creamy mushroom sauce or even some gravy.

text:
I love this recipe and have made it multiple times.  Those of you who say it is lacking flavor, what I suggest is to brine the chicken.  I always brine my chicken, for every chicken dish I make, and it really helps keep the chicken moist and it's always flavorful. That way you can enjoy the buttery taste more instead of focusing on the blandness of the chicken.

userID:
2063227
Display Name:
INeedAllTheHelpICanGet
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I was skeptical... This recipe sounded bland to me, but easy enough to at least try it out for the kids.  Wow! What a surprise.  My only changes: Adding "multi season" season salt to the crumb mixture (No, it wasn't salty)  Spray the bottom of the pan with non-stick spray, reduce the butter to 1/4 cup, use thin slices of chicken breast, lightly spray the chicken with spray butter once in the pan, turn the chicken over half way through and cook on 400 degrees for less time to get a crispier coating. (The chicken was still very moist) My picky 8 year old and her friends loved it (and so did I)!  Another tip, put your cracker crumbs and other seasoning in a large zip lock bag and use a rolling pin to get a finer crumb mixture - better for coating).

I just made this recipe last night. My entire family loved it. The chicken was moist and very flavorful. I did make a few changes to the recipe. I used garlic and herb crackers. I also seasoned the chicken to give it extra flavor. I used only 2 table spoons of butter. I sprayed the pan with olive oil and the chicken and put  butter spray (0 calories) on the chicken to give it more of a butter taste. I also included parmesean cheese in the cracker bowl. It taste great cold also and I took some left over to work so will see how it will taste heated up.
thanks for the recipe.

text:
This was pretty good. I may cut back to 1/4 cup butter next time as I ended up with a lot of liquid butter at the end, or I'll plan a side dish that can utilize the chicken-flavored butter.  Over all though the chicken was decently crispy (used less time to cook than the recipe called for because my chicken breasts were fairly thin) and flavorful. I patted  garlic powder and ground black pepper on the chicken before coating and also added some Tony Chachere's to the cracker crumbs (with the garlic salt and ground pepper). Wonderfully flavorful. My boyfriend doesn't usually like breaded items unless they have a gravy, but this time he ate all he was given and finished off the leftovers!

Fantastic chicken recipe!  Super easy, too!  My husband and children loved it.  I chuckle at all of you worried about the fat content.  At our house we have carb issues, not fat issues.  This actually fits in nicely with my diabetic diet and my husband's low carb diet.  The only carbs are in the crackers, and I think that works about to about 10 g. of carbs per serving.  I made it exactly as printed, and it turned out perfect--very moist.  This is a keeper!  It would be easy to double to feed dinner guests.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, this recipe gave me a GREAT starting point - that's why I only rated it 4 stars - I didn't really follow the recipe.  I'm in Switzerland so many ingredients are not available here.  I used Sesame Crackers for the breading.  I used Pampered Chef Lemon Pepper that I brought from the States for seasoning.  I marinated the chicken in an egg mixture (egg, milk, fresh garlic, Lemon Pepper Seasoning, and some milk) for about 2 hours.  Then, I slit open the breasts and put in some Gruyere cheese.  Then I breaded chicken with the crushed sesame crackers (also added some of the Lemon Pepper seasoning and onion salt to the cracker coating) and baked with maybe a Tablespoon of butter for about 30 - 40 minutes.  It was wonderful.  My fiance loved it and said that it should definitely go in the "make again" category.  I'd still like to see some more spice in it.  Perhaps some Italian Seasoning or spicy pepper as some others have suggested.  Overall - this recipe was a great starter for me - I just took the advice of some others and made it a little differently.  The chicken was extremely moist.

Display Name:
SLBINTX

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I continue to use this great recipe, thank you!!!! and several friends (even one who doesn't cook at all) now make it as well, and it is univerally loved by all, especially kids.  After 7? years of making it, these are the tricks I use... first, I put 2 pats of butter in the bottom of the pan and melt it in the oven before I put the raw, battered chicken in...second, I sprinkle Lowry's after placing the pats of butter around it.  The non-cook's husband loves it and he owns about 20 great restaurants. She makes it using chicken tenders.  One last note, if I don't use good chicken, it's not so good.  If I use the local "safeway-esque" frozen/thawed chicken, it's usually gummy and unpleasant, the better the chicken you use, the better it tastes (i.e. never frozen) most recipes I use aren't like this, but this one really tastes better with fresh chicken.  Also, if it is slightly overcooked, it's not so good, I take it out when the juices just run clear and the pink has just gone away...if it's right on the edge, I'll turn off the oven and just let it sit for a couple of minutes in the oven, then it's done and not overcooked.  Lastly, it cools quickly and is better warm, so it's best pretty much oven-to-table.  Really, thanks for a favorite.

text:
We all loved this and it's  so easy to  make.  I added garlic, garlic-salt, pepper, onion  powder, and   Italian  seasoning  to crumb mixture before  adding  chicken  to  it.  I tripled the recipe  and baked 3 pans of it for 25 minutes. Other reviwers mentioned that the bake time should be for about that long, so I attempted to heed the advice.  However, When I  removed  it  from  the  oven, I discovered  that  I  forgot  to  add  the  butter!!   So, I added the butter, and baked  it for 10 more minutes.  Apparently  this  recipe  is  a no-fail one.  My chicken  came  out  perfect.  Everyone  loved  it , and there  wasn't  one  piece  left!

text:
Made this twice in one week, the second time as sandwiches. My variation was to slice the chicken horizontally so I had two thinner pieces, and to flip them over and run them under the broiler for about 2-3 minutes at the end so both sides were crispy.  Served on buttered, toasted sesame seed buns with shredded lettuce, mayo and onion -- awesome dinner! 5/5 loved it  - can't ask for more than that!

I have never written a recipe review before, but I had to for this one. It is the BEST. My husband said it was the best chicken he has ever tasted. I did change a  few things. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this tonight. I added 1T milk to the egg mixture and added my spices to the egg wash.  I put my cracker crumbs in a ziplock bag.  I dipped my chicken breasts in flour before dipping them in the egg wash, then put them in the ziplock bag to coat with crumbs.  I sprayed my baking dish with non-stick cooking spray and placed breaded chicken breasts in the dish.  I froze 1/2 stick of butter, then grated it over the breasts, as recommended by another reviewer.  I used only 3T of butter to cover my breasts.  I baked them for 30 minutes and they were perfectly done -- crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  Easy, delicious and much lower in fat than the original recipe!

I've tried cutting it out, a big task, but it's not the same.  Can anyone tell me a trick to make the chicken breasts without the lines running through them? This came out very moist & good.  I anticipated it being kid-friendly so added blackening seasoning from "blackened chicken" in the crumbs.  I had six pieces so used 1c crumbs & 1/2c plain bread crumbs.  I melted 6T butter over them after refrigerating.  Baked at 375, but lost track of time.  As it is, good for kids or those sensitive to spices.  Anyone else would appreciate spices added.  If I make again, I'll double the spices.  Girl, 14, liked it & said so without being asked first. text:
This is a fantastic, quick, easy recipe.  I made it tonight and my whole family loved it...including two picky eaters.  I used only half a stick of butter - a whole stick would have been too much for my taste.  I added a bit of onion powder, paprika parmesan, and seasoned salt in with the garlic salt and pepper.  Baked it for about 35 minutes, let it rest for a few and served it with buttered noodles and veggies.  It was delish!  Definitely going into my rotation.  Thanks so much for sharing!

text:
I love this recipe but I'm rating it 4 stars because I make a lot of modifications to it. I add paprika, garlic powder, onion powder and pepper to the mix. I also decrease the cooking time substantially. 

I've found the recipe works fine if you take cold butter, cut it into small pieces and place it on top of the chicken so it melts while it cooks. Turns out great. 

Definitely one of my favorite chicken dishes to serve with some mashed potatoes, corn and/or salad!

text:
OMG this is a GREAT recipe!  Hubs took a package of chicken tenders from the freezer instead of breasts, so decided to try this.  The only change I made was instead of an egg wash, I "marinated" the tenders in buttermilk I had to use up for about an hour.  I used all of the butter and cut it into pats and put one between each tender.  I even baked it longer than the indicated time....about another 30 minutes.....and it was still not dry, and no knife required it was so so tender.  Thanks for a really great recipe that I know I'll use often.  It's surely fit for company!!

text:
Excellent and easy recipe!  I made this in the same oven as the Creamy Au Gratin Potatoes by CathyM.  Since the potatoes needed to be at 400, I only baked the chicken for 30 minutes and kept a close eye on it.  I also used 1/3 cup butter and marinated twice as suggested.  I didn't have quite enough juice to baste the first time I opened the oven, so I put a thin pat of butter on top of each chicken breast. The second basting I just enough to cover each piece of chicken.  Turned out fabulous, my husband and 3 year old loved it.  Thanks!

<3tocook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/935785.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was tasty, but I would definitely just do 1/3 of a cup of butter and spoon over the juices at least twice during the baking process. I double coated the chicken to try and use up the egg and crackers, but before I did that I dabbed the chicken with a paper towel to make it a little dryer and rolled it in some white flour before I dipped it in the egg. It helps to secure the egg onto the chicken so when rolled in the crackers, it all adheres well without falling off. 
Let chicken sit a little while like 10 minutes before serving so the juices can build up in the breasts. 
I also used a Pampered Chef stoneware, so I cooked my 3 breasts for about 35 minutes.

I really, really enjoyed this. If your chicken breasts are thicker, be sure to pound them thinner. The chicken was very moist and delicious. Next time, I might use simply regular salt and pepper. text:
First I butterflied my chicken breasts so they wouldn't be too thick and dry out. Made this using store brand whole wheat ritz like crackers. Double breaded the chicken with eggs and cracker crumbs. Added a little garlic powder to the top and cooked in skillet with some olive oil. Came out with a nice crispy crust. Chicken was nice and moist and not dry, probably because the chicken was not too thick. Worked well in the pan instead of the oven. Was good and will defiantly make again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy and so good!  I used 2 boneless skinless chicken breasts.  Since the butter was salted I just added pepper and garlic powder to the crumbs.  I placed the chicken in a dish just large enough to fit both pieces of chicken in.  Then I placed very thin butter pats on top before baking at 350 (instead of 375).  Halfway through cooking I flipped the chicken over and put butter pats on the other side.  The total baking time was about 30 minutes.  The chicken was very moist and flavorful!  Served with angel hair.

text:
I followed the recipe for the most part.  Only difference is that instead of using garlic salt, I used garlic powder.  I like a lot of garlic, and not so much salt.  Plus I the crackers I used were already salted.  The cut of chicken I used was really thick, so I did end up having to cook it for 40 minutes.  I know a lot of people said 40 was too long, but it all depends on how much chicken you're using.  Overall, this came out awesome - and my husband loved it, which is why I'm giving it the 5 stars!

text:
AWESOME! 10 stars if you had it! This is truly a keeper! Made this today for dinner tonight. Followed to a T, but as I usually do, added a little extra seasonings. Most important part for me is to pound the chicken flat...seems to make it extra tender. Some recommended cut the butter (I didn't end up doing this as I discovered it needed more, due to the amt of chicken I had), I added Grill Mates Chicken rub directly to chicken (I almost always use that on all chicken recipes), + salt, onion powder, extra garlic salt & parm cheese to cracker crumbs, and flour per suggestion of others. Added cloves of garlic to pan w/butter per suggestion and spooned juices over as suggested by others too. I timed it for 25min, but needed a little extra time, due to the # of pcs I had to cook. Tasted a small pc and I can't wait for dinner! My husband came out of his office because it smelled so good! Hope kids like it! Thanks for this YUMMY recipe!

text:
I tried this out Sunday and DH and I agreed that it was very good.  I mostly went by the original recipe except that I only used 1/4 cup butter and I added several spices - seasoned salt, fresh ground Garlic Salt,  steak house seasoning, onion powder.  I think you could use whatever you like or have on hand.  You need to watch the cooking time.  I used boneless skinless chicken tenders.  They only took about 25 minutes to cook.  It would be easy to overcook and have dried out chicken.  This will go into my every day dinners rotation.

I have made this recipe for the last 25-30 years.  I call it oven fried chicken.  It is absolutely fantastic.  You will never have left overs. text:
I have been making this for about a year now and have modified it a bit to our taste.  I use italian bread crumbs for the coating.  We like our food with extra spices, so I season with salt before the dipping and with garlic after being rolled in the crumbs.  The chicken gets crispier and more flavor if you melt the butter first and then poor it evenly over the chicken before baking.  Super recipe, especially with chicken breast tenders.

Very good. I coated the chicken with garlic salt and white pepper before dipping it in the egg, but I kept everything else the same. text:
This was really good!  My all time favorite chicken recipe is Spicy Garlic Lime Chicken though (check it out!).  For this buttered chicken, I made as suggested with some additions.  I ADDED cayenne pepper, onion powder, seasoned bread crumbs, and a few panko (more coarse) bread crumbs to the cracker mix.  I also EGGED AND DREDGED A SECOND TIME  to get more of the crumb mixture on the chicken.  As suggested in another review I PUT A FEW THIN SLICES OF BUTTER ON TOP of the chicken.  As I said before, it was good.  I would definitely make it again.  I only made 2 chicken breasts and I put them into a pie pan for cooking so that the butter would stay close to the chicken. Not good. It wasn't enough space so the bottom got soggy. So, next time I'm make them in a slightly larger pan. HAPPY COOKING!

text:
This is by far my husband's favorite chicken recipe! The recipe turns out right every time, and we can always count on a great meal when I make this. 
We love how tender and moist the chicken is, combined with the heavenly baked-in flavor of butter. The crunchy buttery-cracker topping is awesome, too. I get lots of requests for this dish, and it has become a comfort food dish around our house.
We always like to pair this chicken with either lightly buttered noodles with a little garlic salt, or pre-packaged butter flavor noodles.

text:
My family LOVES this chicken!! My son prefers it when I make it with chicken breast tenderloins because he loves to dip them in bbq sauce.  I don't add any salt to it and instead add garlic powder and black pepper to the cracker crumbs.  The leftovers reheat very well in the toaster oven too. **UPDATE** To make this a little healthier, I've started using the Smart Balance 50/50 Blend instead of the butter.  No one noticed.  :O)

I may have left feedback for this recipe before, but I made it again last night for the first time in a while and had forgotten how tasty it was.  Something else to give the chicken extra 'moisture' and rich flavor...soak it overnight in a bowl of buttermilk.  If your crackers are ground well enough you won't even need to dip the chicken in the eggs. I also just use regular dried garlic rather than garlic salt so I can adjust the sodium more eassily.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/17.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've updated my review as I've learned a few things after making this several times. I have a family of 5 so I use the whole box of crackers (I try to buy reduced fat/sodium to make it healthier).  It is sufficient enough to coat 5 to 6 thick chicken breasts (I don't scale up the rest of the recipe though).  I still use the 9x13 pan (have to squish them in but it works out fine).  I don't bother with placing the butter pieces - I just melt the butter and spoon it on - much quicker and easier.  Personally I don't feel it needs extra seasoning - the original recipe is sufficient for our family. Tip:  all chicken breasts are not created equal - the ones I use are from our local meat shop are quite thick - they take the full 40 min and are not dry at all.  If I were using grocery store breasts (they tend to be thinner) I probably would check them at 30 minutes.  Thanks again for the recipe - it is one of the most requested by my kids.

country:

text:
This turned out much better than I expected. I used Whole Foods Buttery Sticks- & did use the whole stick. Might try half next time. I used Town House crackers- a whole sleeve was a bit much- I would recommend about 3/4 of a sleeve. Used 1 1/2 lbs. chicken breasts- cut into 6 pieces & put in a 13x9. Placed the butter pieces AROUND & in between the chicken- not on top. This way you get a beautifully tender yet crunchy top crust! I love this the way it is- the flavor is wonderful & delicate. Don't add extra spices unless you've given it a go as written first. A low carb treat!!! P.S.- WHY do people like the Purple Chef TOTALLY change a recipe & then rate how THEY made it??? It's just not right.......

text:
This was a good recipe.  For my taste it would be more like 4 star but my husband liked it so much I had to give it a 5.  I did spice it up a little by adding cayenne pepper and celery salt, and a little more garlic to the crackers, and adding a little tabasco and worchestershire to the eggs.  I also used 1/2 the butter and that was plenty.  This is a very basic recipe that I think kids and people that like less favorful foods would prefer.  I dipped mine in Horseradish Sauce (from this site...AWESOME dip for anything from onion rings and breaded chicken to roasts) and that was really good.  My husband said "this is the best chicken I have ever had" so that summed it up for me.  This will be in my normal; rotation now.  Thanks for posting!

text:
The best baked/breaded chicken! I made half as the recipe said and half low fat, and the low fat were pretty darn good, just didn't have the same nice texture of the reg. Do this for lower fat: Use reduced fat Ritz crackers, dip in egg beaters, and spray the pan down and the top of the chicken with butter flavored cooking spray.

Loved it!  I sliced my breasts lengthwise to make chicken strips.  I also added a bit of olive oil along with the butter to keep the butter from browning too much.  Taking a cue from the other reviewers I added more spice, cayenne, garlic and sage.  I also added a little flour and grated parmesan cheese to my cracker crumbs.  It was wonderful.  Can't wait to try it with pork!  Jeanne Bean

text:
YUUUMMMM! I believe that my husband will be a little upset that I have a new love, This recipe!
I took this to a Pot Luck a work so I made it the night before and we had to "sample" it before I took it, and we at 4 strips that night! This dish was gone in 60-seconds and I had many people ask for the recipe- so I told them, go to Allrecipes!
 This recipe will be a great help to working moms, 5 minutes is all it takes and then you pop it in the oven and you can do other things while it watches itself. Be sure to serve it with the Honey Mustard recipe found on this site! The kids will flip over this one and MEN if you want to cook to impress- GO WITH THIS ONE, you can't go wrong! (I used half Ritz crackers, and half Chicken in a biskit crackers for a more flavorful taste) Try sprinkling Parmesan cheese on it and serving over Speghetti! SO MANY WAYS, SO LITTLE TIME!

text:
Oh man, this is the real deal.  Following the comments of other reviewers, I added Italian seasoning, onion powder, Parmesan cheese, and a bit of flour to the crumb mix.  I also reduced the butter to 1/3 cup.  With the thin-sliced breast filets I was using, 30 minutes (turning halfway through) was the ticket.  Both of my boys wanted more of the chicken and asked "Can we have this every time we do chicken?"  It's simple, relatively foolproof, and tastes amazing.  Definitely a keeper!

UPDATE: Cooked it again, same result.  Great go-to simple recipe!

text:
This recipe is very easy, and it's great for a last minute supper, given that it uses ingredients that I always have on hand. Since chicken breasts are now so large, I sliced each one in half, and pounded it to a uniform thickness, before dipping it into the egg and dredging in the crumb mixture.  In addition, I sliced 2 tablespoons of the butter very thinly, and dotted the tops of the chicken with it, and put  the remainder of the butter around the chicken, as directed. My fiancé and his roommate practically licked the platter!

userID:
5218078
Display Name:
Cyndie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great quick fix for dinner.  I cut my chicken breasts in half (which means less cooking time, maybe 30 minutes).  I coat in egg, then bread with crushed Ritz crackers that has garlic salt, onion powder, and pepper in it as well.  Be careful with adding too many spices that have salt in them due to the Rtiz crackers already having salt on them.  I melt butter and drizzle it over the chicken after I put them in the pan (I also add some to the bottom of the 9x13 before I place the chicken so they don't stick).  I sprinkle some shaved garlic in the pan so it can marinate w/the butter.  I increase the butter a little b/c I use the sauce at the end for rice or noodles.  This is the type of recipe that you can play with quite a bit and suit to taste - but this one is a winner for me and my family.  Have fun!

text:
delish!  Here are some more helpful hints. 1. mix melted butter and your spices like garlic, onion salt, italian seasonings etc all together and use a marinade injector to infuse the flavor into the chicken before cooking. makes it extra juicy and flavorful. 2. butterfly the chicken breast almost all the way, leaving a small portion in tact and stuff with butter, cheeses, bacon etc of your choice place the top layer back down on the chicken then dip in egg wash and crumbs before cooking and you get amazing flavor as well!  3. marinade over night in a mixture of olive oil, butter, garlic and italian seasonings ( reserve some for basting while cooking or for infusion with a marinade injector.    a quick tip is use feta cheese to stuff the chicken: it melts well and is extremely flavorful in the chicken!

text:
Needed a lot more garlic and some more salt to have enough flavor.  Like others suggested, I also halved the butter, and that turned out fine.  I garlic salted them before dredging (but still used the garlic salt as suggested.).  But I first dredged in flour, and THEN eggs, and then the cracker crumbs.  Generally, if I dip in flour first, they will be moister after cooking.  Next time, I would add a loit more garlic without adding more much more salt.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! #1: I don't like chicken breasts and am very picky about my chicken. #2: This was amazing, juicy, tasty, and other yummy adjectives. #3: I've changed my mind about disliking chicken breasts -- I'll cook em this way forever! I had 6 medium chicken breasts and had to use 2 sleeves of coarsley crushed Ritz crackers (baked 30 minutes - they were perfect). I really patted the crackers into the chicken, and topped the breasts with the leftovers from the dredging plate. I did not baste, but I will next time. I was afraid the butter would make the tops soggy, not thinking the butter will crisp up the crackers! Advice: add extra broken up crackers around the chicken in the dish, the butter frys them up and they're buttery, crispy & delicious on top of the chicken! Hubby said to add extra butter next time too. I don't think you can mess this one up, Ritz crackers, eggs for dredging, a bunch of butter and sprinkles of garlic salt. Surprisingly amazing and very simple!!

None
text:
Tasted terrific, but made some minor changes - in quantities, not ingredients. I was cooking 3 large half breasts, and 1 cup of crumbs was not enough - it barely covered the chicken. I reduced the butter to 1/4 cup, and I also reduced the cooking time to 30 minutes. Came out moist and flavorful. Make sure you really crush your cracker crumbs with a rolling pin. You can also toss in extra spices for fun ... the second time I made this, I added a 1/2 t of sage and a 1/2 t of paprika. Yummy either way.

text:
This is similar to an old oven fried chicken I used to make, only this coating is different.  The rating is for Haulbur's version and mine too.  I took some suggestions of adding some flour to the coating.  Also it only took 1 egg for me to coat my boneless chick breasts.  I melted the butter in the dish before adding the chicken and turned it over halfway.  Watch for doneness according to thickness of the chicken, I don't think it took quite 40 min. to finish.  Thanks, Haulbur, from Susie

Display Name:
Kilyena

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made something similar to this for years.  Instead of cracker crumbs I used flour mixed with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and a little paprika.  I find it is easier and the chicken browns better if you just melt the butter in the casserole dish before adding the chicken.  I put the casserole dish in the oven to melt the butter, then add the chicken.  I always bake my chicken on 350 for about 40 - 45 minutes for bone in and 30 minutes for boneless.  Having said that I really like the difference the cracker crumb gives it. I always use about 1/3 cup of butter which is all that's needed.  My family has already requested this again.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
This recipe was so easy and yummy!!! I used vegetable thins instead of Ritz crackers. It was all I had.I added garlic salt and pepper and parmesan cheese to the crackers. I baked at 400 for 15 minutes uncovered. Then spooned the melted butter on top. I layed foil on top of dish for an additional ten minutes because the crackers were browning. Did not want them to burn.
The chicken turned out perfect. Super moist and flavorful!

text:
I changed this recipe a bit - I seasoned the chicken with paprika. garlic powder, salt, and pepper first. Next, I coated the chicken with mayo (not the healthiest option, but darn tasty) instead of an egg before adding the cracker crumbs. I placed 2 tbsp of butter, in pieces, on top of the chicken, it comes out much better. Baked for 40 minutes at 350 degrees instead of at 375 degrees. Came out really good.

text:
I changed it a little - not because I thought it needed it but my husband has it in his head that he hates crab.  I've made it before without him knowing it but I have to wait until he's not around to get it ready.  I had it mixed and was looking for a recipe for chicken to stuff it with.  This was it.  I took the lazy way and mixed the canned crab with Litehouse Garden Veggie dip, sprayed the kitchen with Fabreze so he wouldn't get the fish smell and other than that, I changed nothing. He asked what was in it and I said "do you like it?"  "Yes".  "Then what does it matter".  Now he knows he wasn't supposed to like it but he still doesn't know what it was.  That's what keeps a marriage together - deception!  --only on this scale!  Anyway, mmmmm mmmmm good !

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This didn't quite turn out as crispy as I'd hope, but I'm willing to bet it was a cook error (me) and not a problem with the recipe.  Even though it wasn't super crispy, it was still delicious and worthy of five stars.  Super easy to make on a weeknight.  I took others advice and added italian seasoning to the cracker crumbs along with some onion powder.  I followed other  suggestions and baked at 375 for 35 minutes with perfect results.  Super moist chicken. I also let is rest for 10 minutes as others had suggested.  I had very large breasts so I sliced each down the center to create two thinner breast pieces out of each.  Worked great.  Served with mashed potatoes and ceasar salad because it's the family's favorite salad.  I ate my chicken just as it was cooked, but my teenage daughter dipped hers in ranch and loved it.  Great recipe.  Thanks for the post and the suggestions of so many others.  Will keep this in my binder as a go to on a busy night.

text:
YUM!!!  This was so good, I was so surprised.  I dredged my chicken in flour first, then egg, then the cracker mixture.  I used a few tablespoons of butter, but there wasn't much to drizzle over the top, which was ok because I flipped them halfway through and then sprinkled the top with shredded parmesan cheese.  The chicken is so amazingly moist, but the coating is not crispy (if that is something you are going for).

text:
Very tasty dish!  The garlic adds a very nice touch.  Make sure not to overcook the chicken so as to keep the juiciness of the meat, and don't put the butter on top of the chicken, just around the sides.  The crackers are delicious and I was surprised at how crispy this came out.  A definite keeper!

text:
I'm rating this as 4 stars because I think the original recipe is quite bland. I read reviews before making and took everyone's advice: I cut down on the butter and added much more seasoning to the cracker mix. I added onion powder, paprika, lemon pepper and garlic powder. I also followed another reviewer's suggestion and dipped in lemon juice instead of egg. Came out very lemony and everyone loved it :) I'll try dipping in egg next time.

This is one FANTASTIC! recipe!  The chicken was so tender you didn't need a knife to cut it, a fork worked just fine.  I did pound the chicken breast before I dredged in milk and crumb mixture. This is a KEEPER!

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
4127391
Display Name:
Karina7268
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
355
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/643080.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe!! The few changes i made were to dredge the chicken breasts in flour seasoned with ground mustard, paprika, onion powder, garlic powder and chipotle spice. Then I dipped them in an eggwash with about 1 tsp honey, 1 tbsp of sriracha sauce, garlic powder, onion powder and a little lemon zest. I then breaded the chicken with crushed ritz crackers seasoned with chipotle spice, ground mustard, onion powder and garlic powder. I placed the breasts in a baking dish and placed a little bit of butter around them with some minced garlic, and a larger pat of butter on each breast with the juice from a jar of minced garlic on top of the butter (in case you couldn't tell, i love garlic). I cooked the breasts @ 350 for 15 minutes, flipped them over and baked for another 10 minutes....came out FANTASTIC!! served with chipotle mac and cheese from this site

This was fantastic.  My husband said this was the most tender chicken he has ever ate...And he usually has a minor complaint about everything!  I melted the butter in a baking dish in the oven first.  Next time I will use slightly less butter, I ended up pouring some of the butter out before it was done so that it would "crisp" up.  I also added minced onion and paprika to the garlic, salt, and pepper mixture.  I also flipped the chicken once about halfway through.  Overall, it was probably the best chicken I've ever eaten.

Display Name:
Lamb in Kit

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/289965.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is probably the moistest chicken that I have cooked. Other reviews are helpful with this recipe: use 1/4 c of butter and place the cooling rack inside the baking dish in order to prevent the chicken from tasting soggy. Chicken breasts usually take 30 minutes to bake evenly (using the cooling rack required 35-38 minutes for my chicken to cook though).  Using fresh rosemary is an easy way to add great flavor and aroma. I chopped two sprigs of fresh rosemary and garlic (2 cloves), and combined them with the cracker crumbs (easy as pie in a zip lock bag).  I used the remaining rosemary on red bliss potatoes, which were a nice complement to the chicken. This website has a great and easy recipe for red bliss potatoes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe! It's by far my favorite recipe for breaded, baked chicken that I've ever used. I used chicken breast tenderloins (about 7 small pieces), and for my crumb mixture I used a sleeve of Ritz crackers, Italian seasonings, flour, pepper onion powder and Parmesan cheese. I sprayed the bottom of the dish with cooking spray, and only used about 2 tablespoons of butter pieces around the chicken. I sprayed the tops of my chicken to give them that extra crispiness. I only had to cook mine for about 27 minutes and it was so tender I didnt even need a knife! My chicken didn't get soggy and i didn't have problems with the breading falling off or sticking to the bottom of the pan like I usually do-must be the buttery crackers. Anyway, this will be a staple in my recipe box for crispy breaded chicken from now on! Thanks!

Easy, delicious, tender, and moist.   I will never use the "Shake and Bake" product again.  There is no comparision. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/231443.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome chicken.  I don't use garlic salt. I use garlic powder and salt seperately. Sometimes things need more garlic seasoning and I don't want to add additional salt to the dish.  I mixed the garlic powder in with the crumbs and I also added it to the egg mixture.  I sprinkled in some paprika for a bit of color and I added some minced onion to give it a little bit more flavor.  I had to set 2 cutlets aside for my daughter who was working late and I was afraid that they would be mushy when I put them in the oven when she got home but they turned out just as crispy and delicious as the ones I made earlier in the evening. So this is a recipe you can put together quickly and easily and pop in the oven when you want to eat.  Next time I might coat the chicken with lite mayo and then in the cracker crumbs. Thanks for sharing.

text:
This was very tasty. I did add 1/4 cup of flour to the cracker crumbs, after the chicken was well coated I then seasoned them with garlic/onion powder and pepper. I poured 1/2 stick of melted butter over the chicken breasts. I cooked them in a 8&8 dish, I only had 3 breasts but they were in there pretty tight. Unfortunately mine didn't turn out pretty. They tasted great though! The next day I reheated them in the oven on a pan, at 400 degrees, for about 10 min each side. They tasted great reheated, do not reheat in the microwave -- that would not be pretty! (yuck)

country:
None
text:
Instead of dipping in eggs, coat chicken pieces (generously) in sour cream that's been mixed with 1 tablespoon of Lawry's seasoning salt, then coat in the crackers. Bake at 275 for 1 hr 15 minutes, do not skimp on the butter and do not cover with foil. It cooks slow and uncovered so that the coating does not melt off the chicken. This is an old church recipe that is so popular with everyone, they serve it when they want a big turnout.

text:
I'm always on the lookout for toddler friendly food and with a little variation, this recipe was perfect!  I cut the breasts into strips, then dipped them in egg and coated them with cracker crumbs.  Also, I used my coffee grinder to grind the crackers very fine so I could get a good, even coating.  Whip up a little dipping sauce (or open a jar like I did) and you've got tasty chicken fingers any toddler will love!  The best part was that they cooked in only 13 minutes!  Quick and easy!  Kuddos!

text:
I have been making this recipe for a few years now and never fails to draw raves from family and friends. Recently, I began adding adobo (the powder version, not the sauce) to the bread crumbs instead of the garlic powder and it has enhanced the flavour quite well. You can find adobo in some supermarkets and most definitely in a Latin store. Enjoy!

text:
This recipe is as simple as it gets.  I added the fab four of chicken seasonings (Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and Thyme); you can really season it how you like it and the flavor was GREAT.  It was tender, too.  But I don't know if I did something wrong, but I expected a nice crisp crust that just didn't happen.  The crackers formed a pastey white goo on the bottom, so I thought I'd flip it over and give it an additional 5-7 minutes.  Bad idea.  When I took it up, all the breading stayed in the pan.  Still in all, it was flavorful and there were no leftovers.

text:
I’ve always had trouble with dried baked chicken, this recipe solved that problem, I like to experiment with recipes to see what works and what doesn’t, while I was crushing the crackers I soaked the pierced chicken in the beaten egg, then added coconut flakes to the cracker crumbs, I know it sounds wired but it came out really good..  It was semi sweet with a buttery flavor, everyone loved them and the chicken came out really moist, I baked them for about 25 min. covered then broiled them for about 3 minutes uncovered to toast the coconut.. Fabulous.. This is a keeper.. Thanks for sharing

text:
I am giving this 5 stars because I think this would ahve been awesome IF I had not messed it up. I found some boneless skinless chicken thighs on sale at Sam
s cluba nd decided to use those instead of chicken breasts. I am warning all of you, DO NOT DO THAT! The texture of the chicken thighs was gross. I have never even eaten a boneless chicken thigh before and neither had my husband and we thought it was SICK. I could tell that if I had not used that choice of meat that this would have been SO good. I am going to try this again and use the chicken breasts. I am telling you you evidently get what you pay for, I wish I had paid full price and got the chicken breasts instead. The flavor of the crust was good, it was the meat that just killed it. Dont make the mistake I did!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was soooo good!  We made a few minor modifications though.  We used 2 chicken breasts (as opposed to 4), but kept the rest of the ingredients as is and we found that we had barely enough cracker crumbs to coat two breats.  We also did not use garlic salt as I'm not a fan - but instead we crushed two cloves of garlic into the egg mixture.  As well, we followed the suggestions of some other reviewers and we didn't put 1/2 cup of butter around the chicken, instead, we melted about 1/4 cup and drizzled it over the top of the chicken.  This made the cracker crumbs toasted and crunchy.  Very good dish - we will definitely make again.

Chicken was moist, coating was crispy.  It was easy to prepare. I only used 1/2 of the butter and used an 8x8 pan.  I dredged the chicken in flour, then egg, then the crackers and had no trouble with the coating falling off.  I think the flavor might have been better if the seasoning was added to the flour or sprinkled right on the chicken before coating.  That's how I'll do it next time.  This one is a keeper :-)

text:
Not the healthiest chicken but it can be a good change from shake-n-bake.  I put all the crumbs garlic salt and pepper in a large zip lock bag the tossed the chicken in the bag.  I used Market Day Chickensteaks and baked them in a 8x8 baking dish.  I did not use all that butter.  I only used about 2 tablespoons and placed them around the chicken not on top, placing the butter on top tends to "wash" away the crumb coating.  I will make again next time I will add a little more spice to the cracker crumbs.

text:
I was sceptical about this.  I have often been disappointed by highly rated recipes.  However, this chicken had an excellent flavor and was very moist.  I added extra seasonings (paprika, onion powder, etc.) to the cracker crumbs, skipped the egg (rinse your chicken breast with water to help hold the coating), and used less butter.  I served with some sauteed vegetables (onion, peppers, mushrooms, zucchini in a little olive oil...and a couple of large spoonfuls of my homemade salsa at the end), and crusty rolls.  Husband loved it.  He commented that in cooler weather it would be great with a side of alfredo pasta or mashed potatoes.  The bonus for me was that this was so easy.  I will keep this in mind for those times that I have a million things demanding my attention...I will burn off the calories, then.

country:

text:
This chicken was good, but after the rave reviews it got, I guess I was expecting more.  I added so much spice to the cracker crumbs, and it STILL needed more.  Be generous, it will only help.  The butter flavor was good, though.  To make things easier, I threw the crumbs and seasonings into a ziploc and after egging the chicken, shook it up in there - worked well.  I also put alittle tin foil on the bottom of the dish which helped considerably with the clean up.  The cooking time definately needs to be less than 40 minutes - I cooked mine for 25 and they were perfect and juicy.  Served with the Honey Mustard Sauce from this site.  Will try again for sure, however I will add much more seasoning!

text:
I  knew it would be bland with the few spices listed so I added 1 tsp. italian seasoning, 1/4 tsp. garlic powder and 1/2 tsp.pepper. Also added salt and pepper to beaten eggs. I slightly pounded my chicken to about 1/2 inch thick.I used all the crumb mixture. Checked baking progress every 15 min. After 30 min. crust wasn't brown so left in 5 min more. The flavor was good from seasonings but we weren't that impressed with the overall outcome. Son said it was o.k.and daughter said it was good but not great. I am a perfectionist when I cook and it is my passion and I just wasn't overly thrilled with this.I think boneless chicken breast is tricky to bake. You want to make sure it's cooked through,but you don't want to over cook because it becomes dry very easily. I may try to make again,only I would try frying it instead. Thanks Heather for sharing!

text:
I was really disapointed in this recipe.  I followed the advice of others and added a little garlic powder to spice it up, but it was still a little bland.  It was incredibly greasy because of all the butter.  The bottom of the chicken pieces were greasy and the tops was dry.  If you want it to be uniformly greasy, then I suggest turning the pieces.  Maybe it would have been better had I used half as much butter as the recipe called for.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipie was very quick and easy.  I enjoyed it as did my 2 year old, but my 4 year old wouldn't touch it (he doesn't eat much but ziti) and my 14 year old seemed to like it.  The only thing I would do differently is to add the amount of butter it called for.  I used "I can't believe it's not butter light" which worked fine because we personally like it, but I reduced the amount of butter by half and although it was still moist, I think I would have liked it much more with the full amount.  Also, it does need to be seasoned a little more than the recipie calls for.  I added some garlic powder and season salt and it was pretty good. All in all, I would definitely make it again.

I will definitely use this recipe again.

text:
My son yelled “we just had chicken last night” as I was preparing it. He dislikes most everything. He is now eating it without a single complaint. We all love it. We generally don’t do carbs but this is excellent and there are ways to make it healthier. I served it with asparagus. 
1. I used Trader Joe’s round butter crackers. The ingredients are a bit healthier than standard butter rounds like Ritz. 
2. I melted a small amount of butter and added salt, garlic, and a few other basic spices to it. I rubbed it over the chicken BEFORE coating it in egg.
3. For baking I used a bit less than 1/4 c of butter. I cut it in very small pieces and dotted it around the chicken (I used 2 very large/thick chicken breasts).
4. I baked at 375 for 45 min. If you are using smaller pieces of chicken then 35-40 should be plenty.  I cooked them in a square glass pan.

4

I used thinner breasts - I actually cut them in such a way that they were more like thick cutlets.  I also cut down on the butter, since they were thinner. I made them for a friend that can't cook for himself and wants to eat a bit healthier and he raved about them.  I also set some aside for my kids, and they loved them as well!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5763936.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hands down one of my favorite recipes.  For the crackers I like to use Ritz low-salt or no-salt crackers and add a tablespoon more of garlic salt to offset it.  In addition, I add about 1/2 cup of grated Parmesan cheese to the crackers for additional flavor.  Finally, about 10 to 15 minutes before I'm done cooking, I use a baster to suck up the melted butter in the pan and drizzle it all over the chicken for extra buttery taste and to keep it moist.  It tastes excellent, even as a leftover.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
20387050
Display Name:
Melissa Kilgore
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3924831.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Definitely will add this into the rotation, it's super easy, does not dirty many dishes, and pretty good. 

I made changes after reading previous reviews, and also I was only making this for myself and my 3 year old, so I adjusted the ingredients for 2 people - 
Added a touch of flour to the crumb mixture to help it stick. I used a sleeve of Ritz crackers, maybe 1/8 cup of flour (I was eyeballing it, sorry for the inexact measurement), and shook some garlic powder, onion powder and grated parmesan cheese into there as well, then mixed it all up shake and bake style in a ziplock. I also used chicken breast tenderloins (basically chicken strips / fingers) because that's what i keep in the freezer instead of breasts (they thaw and cook faster, and is a more proportionate size  for a toddler).  After dipping in the egg, I dropped the strips into the ziplock and shook them around and smashed the crumbs into chicken. I did end up using less than the amount of butter I was instructed to, and I also put some garlic cloves cut in half in there with the butter. I cooked in a 9x9 dish and the pieces were ready in 20 minutes. 

Once all done the chicken didn't end up looking like KFC as another reviewer said, but it was very tender, not dry, and flavorful. We had it with a side of collard greens. My son ate his whole portion of chicken, which is amazing.
Review:

5

text:
This has been a staple for my very picky family of eaters for the past couple years now.  It was a little too bland for them the first time, but they liked the crunch of the crackers and how moist the butter made it.  So now before I bread it, I season the chicken with Old Bay or some other all seasoning, garlic powder, onion powder, papricka, salt and pepper and I also add a little more seasoning to the cracker mix.  My husband is the pickiest eater and this is one of his favorites now.

Display Name:
Jamie Gillespie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5107721.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a pretty good guide, but I would recommend adding much more garlic powder to your crushed crackers, as well as a similar amount of onion powder and three good shakes of italian seasoning.  Also, butter can be placed on the chicken instead of just around it, but I use only half of what the recipe calls for.  Lastly, begin checking to see if your chicken is done around 20-25 minutes depending on the thickness of your fillets, as this is easy to overcook (I once overcooked this after only 30 minutes) which results in dry chicken.
Review:
Rating:
4

city:

country:

text:
I just made this for dinner tonight.  I crushed the crackers (I used Town House Butter crackers - one sleeve) in a large ziplock with a good dash of Italian Seasoning, a good dash of grated Parmesan cheese, and a good dash of garlic powder California seasoning blend.  After dipping the chicken in the beaten eggs I tossed them in the ziplock like shake and bake.  I did follow the guidance of others and used 1/2 the amount of butter which was plenty and I baked only for 30 minutes...the last 2 under broil to brown the tops a bit.  I was amazed at how juicy the chicken came out!  I had to double check that it was actually done because other baked chicken recipes I’ve made cake out so dry.   I made this with red potatoes cut into fry pieces mixed with melted butter, salt and garlic, baked for 40 minutes on the rack under the chicken which I put in 10 minutes after the potatoes.  This chicken even impressed my teenaged son who is pretty picky.  He even ate the leftover piece.  BIG hit and now a go-to chicken recipe I will make often.

This is an easy week night recipe that got high marks at our  house.  Like other reviewers, I cut back the amount of butter to 1/2 stick and added seasoning to our tastes to the cracker crumbs. I added Italian seasoning, Parmesan cheese, and a little flour to the cracker mixture.  I also pounded the chicken breasts to a thinner more even thickness before breading them.  Flipped the breasts a couple of times during cooking so that they were uniformly crispy. Otherwise they would've been mushy on the bottom

text:
Ahhhmazing!! Of course, we all make changes.  There is no room for chicken breast in my house. I used dark meat, I like to play dirty. Boneless chicken thighs, gorgonzola parmesan crackers, paprika, garlic powder, black pepper, half Irish butter + half coconut oil. 30 minutes at 375F. Perfecto. Contrary to what a previous review said that this recipe would not work well with dark meat, it came out juicy, succulent and everything good. I omitted salt because the gorgonzola and Irish butter had enough salt in them. And of course, substituted half of the required butter with coconut oil for a healthier version. I made 6 chicken thighs, husband ate 3 and packed 2 for lunch the next day. I got away with 1. Phheew!

text:
I love this recipe!  This is the first review I have EVER done so that is how much I really like this dish.  I followed the recipe as directed other than using a 1/2 stick of butter not 1/2 cup. I also adjust the cooking time depending on the size of the chicken pieces.  40 minutes is just too long.   As far as the chicken is concerned, I've used chicken tenders, tenderloins, and breasts. If I use breasts, I usually cut them a little smaller and tenderize with a mallet before coating with egg and cracker crumbs.  You can cut them with a fork when they are finished.  So yummy!  My family, even my husband, who prefers dark meat, loves this recipe.  I will definitely continue to make it!

I always seem to have a different cooking experience. We just got new appliances that we've been cooking with for approximately two months so they're broke in. I cooked for brass according to the recipe for 25 minutes and the internal temperature was 130°. I added an additional 10 minutes and all but one reached 165°. I would say a proper good time would be between 30 to 35 minutes unless you're just trying to build up your immune system. Otherwise the finished product was delicious and juicy.

text:
The recipe itself was a nice base for me to edit and change up a bit. I used saltines crackers instead. I put the saltines in a plastic ziplock bag, and added seasonings (garlic salt, onion, powder, seasoning salt, and red pepper flakes). I then added minched garlic to the egg. I soaked the chicken in the egg and then tossed in the ziplock bag to the chicken coated. I noticed the crackers were falling off and not sticking well. After shaking on the crackers, I repurchase each breast back into the egg mixture and coated a second time with crackers. I put them in a smaller pan, and used 1/2 the butter. They turned out great.

text:
I gave it 3 stars and hubby gave it 5 so we'll meet in the middle at 4.  It was just "meh"... very bland.  I fixed this exactly as the recipe said to.  Made no changes.  The chicken was moist, but there just wasn't much flavor other than the butter.  I noticed that a lot of reviewers said there was too much butter, but I used what was called for and there was very little left in the pan that the breading hadn't soaked up.  The breasts I used were very large so I cooked them for about 35 minutes and they were perfectly cooked.  My husband wants me to make this again, and I will oblige him but next time I'm going to add some additional spices and maybe go with half butter and half evoo.  I served our dish with rice and asparagus.

text:
It was pretty good! Mine turned out to be soggy unfortunately, however I think it was probably on my end as I added a few extra ingredients. I made an extra breast so I added a bit more garlic salt and pepper, and I also added a fourth to half a teaspoon of paprika, poultry seasoning, and onion powder. My egg wash was also modified by two tablespoons of buttermilk and about a tablespoon of ranch, which probably contributed to the sogginess. I also skipped on the butter, because my brother did not want any (and hey, it's healthier, so why not). 
My mom and brother liked it though! My brother seared it in a pan for a tiny bit to get rid of that soggy flavor and my mom was impressed with me (I'm 14 and I'm just learning to cook, lol) and yeah, it was a nice dinner served with applesauce and egg noodles. Thanks Heather!

Love this recipe!
I've made it twice over the past couple of weeks.  The only changes I made was to add 1/4 tsp each of onion powder and dried Italian seasoning to the cracker crumbs and it amped up the flavor very nicely.  I also didn't measure the butter when adding it to baking dish....i just cut up some pieces and "eyeballed" it.  Regardless, the resulting chicken was juicy, flavorful and overall delicious.

This was good!  I used Onion Toasteds in place of the Ritz crackers and don't like garlic so I used a little celery salt in place of garlic salt, but the butter is the magic and this  just couldn't be easier.  Also checked for doneness at 30 minutes, and the chicken was cooked perfectly.  This recipe would be so easy to tweak to your own taste preferences and what you have on hand.  No leftovers -- will definitely make this again!

Display Name:
Sally Ellsworth

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3810903.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this every other week because my 8-year-old and 42-year-old love it, as do I. My 42-year-old also makes it from time to time, because he can do it without fear of messing it up! I always use chicken breast tenderloins so that the 8-year-old equates it with chicken strips, and I increase the amount of Ritz crackers and eggs to accommodate the extra chicken. I use the amount of butter and seasonings specified and have never had a problem. After all, I'm not making this dish for a 5-star restaurant type of audience. My patrons put ketchup all over it so it doesn't matter what I season it with. Also, I bake this at 400 degrees for 20ish minutes. Honestly, I set it for the wrong temp and time the first time I made it because I didn't have the recipe in front of me, but it turned out great. I just keep doing it that way! Always moist and yummy.

this recipe is good but not the best. i breaded the chicken then browned it each side 3 minutes over medium heat stove top with 4tbsp oil and then baked 30 mins as directed uncovered  but turning at 15 minutes. how i made it makes it not soggy! dont forget to grease your baking pan or you will end up losing all of your breading!

text:
I just absolutely love this dish! So easy to make and it turns out so moist and flavorful. One thing I did do during the prep, before I prepped the chicken, I  took a knife and put a shallow cut down the middle of the chicken and lay the chicken where the cut faces upwards,  so it would absorb more of the juice and flavor of the butter! I highly recommend for anyone who loves chicken.

Display Name:
Laura Moore

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1629780.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this chicken!  I do add some additional spices (garlic powder, natures seasoning salt, onion powder and paprika) and used 1/2 stick butter.  

I cook primarily in cast iron so I heat up a cast iron skillet while warning the oven and then before placing the chicken in the hot pan, I melt one tab of butter in the bottom of the pan.  Place the chicken in the pan and place the remaining tabs of butter around the chicken.  (Turning the chicken half way through)

This chicken turns out moist and delicious.  It's a wonderful addition to our family favorites.  Thank you for this lovely recipe!

text:
Pretty good, even though I didn't taste much difference in this recipe than any other cracker breaded chicken recipe.  There was a little too much butter that I needed to drain some off and it left the bottom soggy.  I turned on the broiler the last couple of minutes to get the top a little crunchier.  It took about 35 min. cook time for 2 large breasts that I pounded out to a medium thickness.  Overall it was good but I would like a little more seasonings next time for more flavor.  Thanks for the recipe!

*onion  powder

great over all taste though. I will make this again

text:
Very simple to make, and delicious! Instead of using butter crackers, I used Club crackers, and crushed them in a Ziploc with pepper, garlic powder and dried parsley, then added a small amount of milk to my eggs.

I will definitely make this again!!

text:
This is an awesome weeknight recipe.  It's really quick, easy to make, and tastes delicious!  I used 1 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp salt, about 1/4 tsp pepper and almost a full sleeve of whole wheat Ritz.  I used a full stick of frozen butter, and placed slices strategically around and on top of the chicken.  I couldn't have asked for a better cripy/buttery chicken recipe.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my go to dishes for nights I'm not sure what to make and want something simple.  I make it a bit differently.  I add about 1 tablespoon of flour to the crackers.  It seems to stick better that way.  I also add a dash of paprika, onion powder, garlic powder and black pepper.  Then bake as directed.  I find that using a smaller pan is best too, that way the butter stays around the chicken.
